head.title: Theme Out of Africa and Fire-Grilled Meat

hedline.hl1: Theme Out of Africa and Fire-Grilled Meat

abstract.p: M H Reed reviews Mighty Joe Young's restaurant in Hartsdale, NY; photo (M)

block.p: IF one's idea of dining is merely to ''eat at Joe's,'' then this is probably not the right Joe. As at most theme restaurants, Mighty Joe Young's tries for spectacle: beyond the torches at the entrance, diners pass a couple of life-size stuffed wild animals, then encounter film posters and a lounge resembling a colonial outpost on the edge of the veld. The mise-en-scene -- Africa via Hollywood -- suggests the primal and the slightly dangerous, but the hunt is only through the menu.

Unlike that of chain extravaganzas -- those trendy backdrops for burgers, fries and other fast foods -- Mighty Joe Young's menu is ambitious. What sets dishes apart and up a few notches are wood-fired grills and stone ovens that with few exceptions, contributed to the sweet, subtle, deliciously smoky flavor of the food. A brush with marinades or sauces altered the nuance from dish to dish. (Look for the crossed-log logo on the menu.)

IF one's idea of dining is merely to ''eat at Joe's,'' then this is probably not the right Joe. As at most theme restaurants, Mighty Joe Young's tries for spectacle: beyond the torches at the entrance, diners pass a couple of life-size stuffed wild animals, then encounter film posters and a lounge resembling a colonial outpost on the edge of the veld. The mise-en-scene -- Africa via Hollywood -- suggests the primal and the slightly dangerous, but the hunt is only through the menu.

Unlike that of chain extravaganzas -- those trendy backdrops for burgers, fries and other fast foods -- Mighty Joe Young's menu is ambitious. What sets dishes apart and up a few notches are wood-fired grills and stone ovens that with few exceptions, contributed to the sweet, subtle, deliciously smoky flavor of the food. A brush with marinades or sauces altered the nuance from dish to dish. (Look for the crossed-log logo on the menu.)

Scented with cilantro and stretched onto skewers impaling a pineapple top, crisped shrimp Konga proved outstanding. Also profiting from ovens' smoke, pleasantly chewy tentacles of octopus came with a good lemony black and white bean salad. And a special of three huge, gently charred sea scallops arrived on a bed of earthy wild mushroom risotto.

Although studded with hunks of crab meat, compared with other starters, crab cake amounted to nothing special, and a mound of fresh mussels needed a broth of more substance. A collaboration of lemon grass, ginger and fresh basil was promised but undetectable.

Orders for the preferred degree of doneness are taken seriously. Medallion of ostrich makes a frequent appearance on the menu, and it would be a mistake to miss it. This dark meat was lean, supple and flavorful. It would please any diner who appreciates first-rate filet mignon, which was also one of the winners here. Judging by these successes, we would bet on Joe's T-bone steak as well. Only hanger steak -- an old favorite -- disappointed; called ''steak frites,'' ours proved coarse and grainy, and the refried frites were stale. Roasted chicken can be a bore, but fire-roasting brought out its juicy best, and a lovely corn risotto added luxury. Silky tuna steak Japanese style arrived properly rare; we preferred it to salmon in horseradish crust, the fish itself unappealingly hard at the edges.

Key lime tart left a nice citrus pucker, and luscious, soft-centered black and white chocolate cake lived up to its ''gooey'' billing. Served in huge goblets, ice creams might be shared, unless the flavor is espresso, which came with chocolate-covered coffee beans tucked discreetly into the mix.
The crunchy beans delivered an astonishing hit of coffee. But banana, baked in hardened pizza dough, seemed pointless, and creme brulee under a thick topping of torched sugar was as heavy as pudding.

Although diners can have a tasty meal here, standards seem to have slipped, supervision nonexistent. In a half-empty dining room, a hostess had trouble finding another place for our party seated at a table under a faulty, grinding vent. We were told that the air-conditioning system blasting cold air into an already chilly dining room could not be controlled.
Some of the fancy drinks from the Mighty Bar were overly sweet, and the frozen concoctions were overly blended into ice that made mouth and sinuses ache.
Young children are frequent and sometimes noisy diners. (To escape, dine late.) Chairs and floors were sticky and wet.
A three-course dinner averages $37 without drinks, tax and tip. The restaurant is at the intersection of Routes 100A and 100B.
Mighty Joe Young's 610 West Hartsdale Avenue, Hartsdale. (914) 428-6868.
GOOD

ATMOSPHERE -- Deliberately kitschy hunt-and-jungle motif. Large noisy dining areas, lounge and semi-enclosed patio. Fireplace. Paper-covered tables. Careless housekeeping and maintenance. Excellent table service; unaccommodating greeting and seating.
SMOKING -- Bar and lounge.
RECOMMENDED DISHES -- Shrimp Konga, grilled octopus, filet mignon, ostrich, yellowfin tuna steak, ice creams, Key lime pie, black and white chocolate cake.
PRICES -- Lunch and brunch, main dishes, $7 to $22. Dinner, main dishes, $15.50 to $30; $12.50 to $19 for pasta. Children's menu, $8 (includes drink and dessert).
CREDIT CARDS -- Major cards accepted.
HOURS -- Lunch, Tuesdays through Fridays, noon to 3 p.m. Dinner, Mondays through Thursdays, 5 to 10 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 5 to 11 p.m.; Sundays, 4 to 9 p.m. Brunch, Sundays, noon to 3 p.m.
RESERVATIONS -- A good idea on weekends.
WHEELCHAIR ACCESS -- Ramp.

THE RATINGS -- Excellent, Very Good, Good, Satisfactory, Poor. Ratings reflect the reviewer's reaction primarily to food, with ambience and service taken into consideration. Menu listings and prices are subject to change.
DINING OUT
